channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kabul Bank Audit Details Extent of Fraud
item.description: The report asserts that Afghanistan’s largest financial institution existed primarily to allow a narrow clique tied to President Hamid Karzai’s government to siphon riches from depositors.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The chief judge in the Kabul Bank case, Shams Rahman Shams, at center behind desk, listened to a defense lawyer during a hearing this month. The United States has pressed for prosecutions.

item.title: North Korea May Be Planning Rocket Test, Satellite Operator Says
item.description: North Korea has stepped up what could be preparations to launch a new rocket from its Sohae Space Launch Station in defiance of a United Nations ban.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Russian Court Convicts Martial Arts Fighter in Student’s Death
item.description: Rasul Mirzayev was convicted Tuesday of killing Ivan Agafonov, a 19-year-old Russian student, outside a trendy nightclub in the capital in August 2011.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Rebel Leaders in Congo Present Demands for Leaving Goma
item.description: Their list of conditions, like releasing political prisoners and investigation the murders of opposition supporters, was long and unrealistic and meant that an immediate pullout seemed unlikely.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: M23 rebel fighters detain a man they suspect to be from the Rwandan rebel group F.D.L.R., in Goma on Tuesday.

item.title: Changing of the Guard: Chinese Communists, New Leaders Chosen, Prepare for Next Round
item.description: A new generation of Communist Party leaders has barely taken over in China and maneuvering has begun to position their putative successors, known as the sixth generation, to key posts.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Hu Chunhua is one of the party's rising stars. Political analysts say he could be on track to ascend to the Politburo’s elite Standing Committee at the next party congress, in 2017.

item.title: Japan Expands Its Regional Military Role
item.description: The pacifist nation of Japan is trying to raise its profile in a new way, offering military aid for the first time in decades and displaying its own armed forces in an effort to build regional alliances.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coast guard officials from a dozen Asian and African nations, at right, joined a training cruise around Tokyo Bay aboard a Japanese Coast Guard cutter.

item.title: After Benghazi Meeting, 3 Republicans Say Concerns Grow Over Rice
item.description: Senators who met with Susan E. Rice said they would delay her nomination if she was selected to be secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senators Lindsey Graham, left, and John McCain arrive on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to meet with Susan Rice, the ambassador to the U.N.

item.title: Top BBC Figures Acknowledge ‘Errors’ in Reporting Scandals
item.description: The remarks by Chris Patten, the head of the supervisory BBC Trust, and Tim Davie, the acting director general, came as they were addressing a parliamentary panel.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS and ALAN COWELL

item.title: European Finance Ministers Meet Again on Greece
item.description: The agreement means euro zone ministers have unlocked loan installments for Greece that total $56.7 billion.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Yannis Stournaras, the Greek finance minister, said the nation had “fully delivered” on the terms of its most recent bailout.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Report Many Dead in Airstrike on Olive Press
item.description: Syrian rebels accused the authorities of launching an airstrike outside the northern city of Idlib on Tuesday, killing at least 20 people as they waited to have their olives turned into oil.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Lede Blog: Something Missing in Chinese Newspaper's Entirely Accurate Summary of Onion Report
item.description: The Chinese Communist Party's newspaper reported, accurately, that The Onion has named North Korea's Leader the Sexiest Man Alive. The word satire was notably absent from the report.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: France Says It Will Vote in Favor of Palestinians’ U.N. Bid
item.description: The support from France is the most significant boost to date for the Palestinians’ hopes to be granted nonmember observer status, which comes with greater international recognition.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Pakistani Journalist Escapes Bombing Attempt
item.description: A bomb was found under the car of Hamid Mir, who hosts one of Pakistan’s most-watched political talk shows.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Protesters Gather Again in Cairo Streets to Denounce Morsi
item.description: Thousands protested the Egyptian president’s attempt to assert broad new powers, despite his apparent backtracking the night before.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Egyptian man was detained by police officers in Cairo during protests on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
item.description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,142 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Garment Workers Stage Protest in Bangladesh After Deadly Fire
item.description: Thousands of workers demanded justice after at least 112 people died over the weekend in a blaze at a factory in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: By JULFIKAR ALI MANIK and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Thousands of Bangladeshi garment workers demanded justice for the victims of a weekend fire at the Tazreen Fashions factory. It was one of Bangladesh’s worst industrial accidents.

item.title: The Hard Road Back: Prosthetic Arms a Complex Test for Amputees
item.description: War veterans who have lost their upper limbs have found that replicating their complex actions with robotic arms can be excruciatingly difficult.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By JAMES DAO
item.media:description: Cpl. Sebastian Gallegos of the Marines received pioneering surgery that is intended to simplify the use of prosthetic arms.

item.title: Tibetan Protesters Injured in Crackdown; Self-Immolations Continue
item.description: At least four Tibetans have set fire to themselves in recent days, and at least 20 Tibetan students were injured after security forces cracked down on a large protest in western China.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Jailed Under Hugo Chávez, Judge Alleges Prison Rape
item.description: In a new book, Judge María Lourdes Afiuni gives her first public account of an allegation from 2010. The government said she was making it up for political purposes.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MARÍA EUGENIA DÍAZ and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Syrian Rebels, Gaining Savvy, Shift Their Tactics
item.description: Fresh from declaring they seized an airport and an air defense base, Syrian rebels on Monday said they overran a hydroelectric dam in the country’s north, adding to a string of tactical successes.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The bodies of Syrian civilians in a street in the northern city of Aleppo on Sunday, after opposition activists said they were shot by government forces.

item.title: Oil Royalties Bill Ignites Protest and Divides Parts of Brazil
item.description: The legislation, aimed at shifting big portions of royalties from petroleum-rich states along Brazil’s coast, would deal a blow to Rio de Janeiro, the host of the 2014 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: At War Blog: Videos From Syria Appear to Show First Confirmed Hit of Aircraft by Surface-to-Air Missile
item.description: This moment was a long time coming. The ground-to-air war (and the likely government retaliation for this hit) can be expected to be bloodier from here.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Sveta, Pussy Riot’s Perky Antithesis
item.description: Since a pro-Putin fan stumbled into the limelight, media and protest circles have debated the social significance of “Sveta,” a naïve young woman caught in a political circus.
item.dc:creator: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY
item.media:description: Svetlana Kuritsyna praised Vladimir V. Putin in a video interview.

item.title: The Female Factor: Taking Risks in Art and Politics
item.description: The Iranian artist Shirin Neshat says women and political and social turmoil fascinate her most.
item.dc:creator: By AYSEGUL SERT

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Judge Orders Toronto Mayor to Leave Office
item.description: The unusual court order relates to $3,150 that Mayor Rob Ford solicited while a city councilor from lobbyists and corporations for a private children’s football charity.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
